DataElement.preferredDefinition: Categorization of T1-weighted images according to the spin-lattice relaxation time (T1) of the protons that give rise to the MRI signals.

DataElementConcept.preferredDefinition: Any record of an imaging event whether physical or electronic._Quality; a degree or grade of excellence or worth; an essential and distinguishing attribute of something or someone._the continuum of experience in which events pass from the future through the present to the past._A number with no fractional part.::1_The relative importance granted to something._A number of things or events standing or succeeding in order, and connected by a like relation. (from On-line Medical Dictionary)

ObjectClass.preferredDefinition: Any record of an imaging event whether physical or electronic.:Quality; a degree or grade of excellence or worth; an essential and distinguishing attribute of something or someone.

Concepts.definition: Any record of an imaging event whether physical or electronic.
An essential and distinguishing attribute of something or someone; a degree or grade of excellence or worth.

Property.preferredDefinition: the continuum of experience in which events pass from the future through the present to the past.:A number with no fractional part.::1:The relative importance granted to something.:A number of things or events standing or succeeding in order, and connected by a like relation. (from On-line Medical Dictionary)

Concepts.definition: The continuum of experience in which events pass from the future through the present to the past.
A number with no fractional part, including the negative and positive numbers as well as zero.
The relative importance granted to something.
A group or succession of objects, substances, or events arranged in regular order in space or time, connected by a like relation, or forming a kind of chain.

ConceptualDomain.preferredDefinition: Events, people, materials and activities uniquely defined by medical imaging.
ConceptualDomain.origin: DICOM:Digital Imaging and Communications in Medicine

DataElementConcept.origin: ACRIN:American College of Radiology Imaging Network
DataElementConcept.changeDescription: 8/15/08   - Created to support curation of ACRIN GYN MRI data elements.

ValueDomain.preferredDefinition: (mag-NET-ik REZ-o-nans IM-a-jing) MRI. A procedure in which a magnet linked to a computer is used to create detailed pictures of areas inside the body.  Also called nuclear magnetic resonance imaging._Sequence; serial arrangement in which things follow in logical order or a recurrent pattern._Category; used informally to mean a class of things._

ValueMeaning.preferredDefinition: Be specific about something; define clearly.: Different than the one(s) previously specified or mentioned.

Concepts.definition: Be specific about something; define clearly.
Different than the one(s) previously specified or mentioned.

ValueMeaning.changeDescription: Associated concept to VM for TCGA. mc 11/9/12 - reversed concept order to match the semantics of this phrase which is "other" with "specify" as a qualifier/modifier - DW 12-30-2015

ValueMeaning.preferredDefinition: High; greater than normal in degree or intensity or amount.

Concepts.definition: An elevated level or position or degree; greater than normal in degree or intensity or amount.

ValueMeaning.preferredDefinition: A minimum level or position or degree; less than normal in degree or intensity or amount.

Concepts.definition: A minimum level or position or degree; less than normal in degree, intensity or amount.

ConceptualDomain.preferredDefinition: Events, people, materials and activities uniquely defined by medical imaging.
ConceptualDomain.origin: DICOM:Digital Imaging and Communications in Medicine

RepresentationTerm.preferredDefinition: Imaging that uses radiofrequency waves and a strong magnetic field rather than x-rays to provide amazingly clear and detailed pictures of internal organs and tissues. The technique is valuable for the diagnosis of many pathologic conditions, including cancer, heart and vascular disease, stroke, and joint and musculoskeletal disorders. :Sequence; serial arrangement in which things follow in logical order or a recurrent pattern.:Category; used informally to mean a class of things.

Concepts.definition: Imaging that uses radiofrequency waves and a strong magnetic field rather than x-rays to provide detailed pictures of internal organs and tissues. The technique is valuable for the diagnosis of many pathologic conditions, including cancer, heart and vascular disease, stroke, and joint and musculoskeletal disorders.
A serial arrangement in which things follow in logical order or a recurrent pattern.
A grouping of items based on some commonality or by user defined characteristics.

DataElement.changeDescription: Curated to support MGH Imaging trial
